llm_processed_output.source_summary: This document is a research paper focusing on Morocco under French Protectorate, specifically addressing the Treaty of Fez (معاهدة فاس) and its implications. The paper explores the conditions leading up to the treaty, the treaty itself, reactions to it (both domestic and international), and the subsequent era under French protection, including resistance movements and the eventual independence of Morocco. The research is divided into four main sections: The situation in Morocco before the French Protectorate, The Treaty of Fez in 1912 and the reactions to it, Morocco under the French Protectorate, General Lyautey’s policies in Morocco from 1912 to 1925. It covers key figures like Sultan Abd al-Hafiz, General Lyautey, and resistance leaders, as well as events such as the Battle of Isly and the Agadir Crisis. The paper also discusses the internal and external factors that led to the imposition of the protectorate, including the weakening of the Moroccan state, European powers rivalry over Morocco and the various international agreements regarding Morocco prior to the establishment of the Protectorate. It also delves into the impact of the protectorate on Moroccan society and the struggle for independence, culminating in the end of the French protectorate in 1956.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: The article "Constructing an Archival Cityscape: Local Views of Colonial Urbanism in the French Protectorate of Morocco" by Stacy E. Holden, published online on May 9, 2014, discusses the urban landscape of Morocco during the French Protectorate (1912-1956). It argues that existing studies often overlook the role of Moroccans in shaping urban life. Holden's research in Moroccan archives reveals primary sources that show Moroccans as active agents in the social history of trades, neighborhoods, and institutions within the medina. The article notes the segregation of the medina from the Ville Nouvelle, built for European use, by French administrators. It suggests that ordinary Moroccans were more concerned with local issues and relationships than with the French authorities. The paper focuses on the experiences of millers and butchers in Fez and discusses five types of documentation to reconsider Moroccan influence on urban development: municipal archives, archives of the Department of Fine Arts, documentation on religious endowments, land titles, and transcripts of judicial proceedings. The article touches on the French Protectorate era in Morocco, which began with the Treaty of Fez, thus it is related to the event "معاهدة فاس المؤسسة للحماية".

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This article examines the transformation of Islamic property and evidentiary law in colonial-era Morocco, specifically focusing on the concept of 'shufʿa' (preemption) in relation to the French Protectorate (1912-1956) established by the Treaty of Fez (معاهدة فاس). It analyzes how French courts and sharīʿa courts adjudicated land preemption disputes, considering the impact of the colonial land registration system (immatriculation foncière) and codified versions of Islamic law. The article argues that French courts created a hybrid version of Islamic property law where immatriculation supplanted traditional Islamic legal modes of proof, resulting in a competing and exclusionary version of sharīʿa. The study relies on sharīʿa and French court records, Islamic legal texts, colonial legislation, and French archives to support its claims. It explores the status of Islamic law and property in the Protectorate, particularly the founding Sharifian Decrees, the Moroccan-Mālikī norms of shufʿa, and paradigmatic cases adjudicated in both sharīʿa and French courts, examining the impact of codification and land bureaucracy. The article also examines specific examples such as 'knowledge' of a co-owner's sale, the 'true' sale price, and the importance of the property immatriculation process, tying the legal changes to the broader historical narrative of French colonial rule in Morocco after 1912.

The Protectorate’s founding legislation formally reserved native personal status matters for religious and customary courts, yet it split competency for real property between sharīʿa courts and French courts.

Upon immatriculation of real property, French courts received exclusive jurisdictional competency and applied a codified droit de préemption (“right of preemption”) that mimicked the stipulations of shufʿa set forth by the Mālikī school (madhhab) of Islamic law.

A 1913 Sharifian Decree on Immatriculation of Immobile Property allowed landowners to submit their properties to the office of Property Conservation (Fr., conservation foncière; Ar., muḥāfaẓa ʿaqāriyya).

A successive 1915 Sharifian Decree promulgated an expansive slate of regulations that built on the 1913 Decree, specifying the eligibility, legal effects, and impact of immatriculation on other property concepts.
Chapter ii of Title ii of the 1915 Sharifian Decree on Immatriculation included ten articles (25–34) that addressed “the law of preemption” on registered property.
The state-imposed coexistence of these two jurisdictions presents a unique opportunity to assess the impact of codification and the public land bureaucracy on adjudicating Islamic property concepts.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: The provided text is an extract from an article titled "Agency in International Law" published in the American Journal of International Law in October 1940. The article discusses the concept of international agency, where one subject of international law acts on behalf of another, and the legal consequences thereof. The author, Angelo Piero Sereni, uses the Treaty of Fez (March 30, 1912) as an example to illustrate the application of international agency in establishing protectorates. The article explains that when a state, duly authorized, concludes a treaty for another state, the latter is bound by the treaty as if it had concluded the treaty itself. This principle applies to situations where one state represents another in international relations, leading to a split between the acting international person and the person to whom the legal effects are attributed. This legal framework helps in understanding the international law principles at play in the Treaty of Fez and the establishment of the French Protectorate in Morocco.

The text elaborates on the structure, regulations, and functions of these special jurisdictions, including Islamic and rabbinic tribunals, emphasizing their role in controlling the Moroccan population, particularly in rural areas. The study also discusses the instrumentalization of the Jewish community and the control over Islamic justice through Habús and other jurisdictions. It mentions the differing approaches of Spanish and French administrations towards Berber customary law. The conclusion asserts that despite official claims of judicial independence, Spanish intervention in indigenous justice was a consistent practice during the protectorate, aiming to control the population and co-opt local authorities.

Majzenian officials, representatives of the Sultan's political power, had jurisdiction over punishable offenses, commercial matters, and public interest, utilizing 'urf (pre-Islamic custom) and iŷtihâd.

Berber customary law was administered by tribal councils or arbitrators in areas with limited central government influence, primarily recognizing spiritual sovereignty while paying annual tribute to the Majzen.

The article highlights the US's limited strategic and material interests in the region and how its attitude was often shaped by its perceptions of the conflicting actors, particularly France and Spain. The US grew wary of France's actions in the Alawi Protectorate and considered supporting Spain to counterbalance them. However, the US's support for Spain was contingent on a significant change in the US's perceptions of the Spanish government and its character. The article discusses the US involvement in the Algeciras Conference, its concerns about French monopolistic aspirations in Morocco, its evolving views of Spain's capacity for successful colonization, and the Anglo-American collaboration at the Versailles Peace Conference to shape the future of Morocco. It details US attitudes towards the Tangier question and the evolving perspectives on France and Spain throughout the 1920s, highlighting the influence of stereotypes and the perceived impact of Primo de Rivera's dictatorship on US policy.

While the main focus is on literary analysis and cultural hybridity, the paper directly mentions the Conferencia de Algeciras (1906) and the Tratado de Fez (1912), which established the Spanish protectorate in Morocco, as crucial historical events that shaped the relationship between Morocco and Spain and contributed to cultural hybridization. extracted_key_facts: The paper analyzes processes of hybridization and interculturality in Larbi El-Harti's book 'Después de Tánger'.

The paper references Néstor García Canclini's study on hybridization processes.
The paper references Homi Bhabha's theory of interculturality.
Morocco and Spain have a long shared history that has led to cultural hybridization.
The Arab/Muslim conquest of Spain in the 8th century lasted almost eight centuries.
The War of Africa (1859-1860) involved Spain and the Sultanate of Morocco.
The Conferencia de Algeciras (1906) entrusted the politics of Morocco to France and Spain.
The Tratado de Fez (1912) established the Spanish protectorate, lasting until 1956.
These historical events have generated cultural and literary outcomes, including the founding of newspapers and the publication of texts by Moroccan authors writing in Spanish.
Larbi El-Harti's literature is considered a hybrid phenomenon, revolving around two distinct cultural and linguistic systems.
El-Harti's characters are often middle-class students or professionals who travel to other cultures and return transformed.
The characters often experience the phenomena of in-between, unhomely, and going beyond.
The characters in El-Harti's work transcend the binary of Orient/Occident, Morocco/Spain, and inhabit a plane of hybridization and creativity.
El-Harti uses hegemonic resources like language and traditional Arab-Islamic culture to critique his own tradition and evaluate hegemonic culture.
The stories in 'Después de Tánger' explore the encounters and disagreements between the peoples of North Africa and Europe, particularly Spain.
The character Ghanu in "Mi vecina Ghanu" represents a living and heterogeneous Morocco.
Ghanu's relationship with Mercedes and Manuel Villaseca, Spanish republicans exiled during the Spanish Civil War, is presented as a paradigm of dialogue between Morocco and Spain.
The story "La Alienada" presents the hybridization process of a character searching for belonging to humanity.
The character Rosa in “Me llamo Rosa” is a Spanish doctor who experiences hybridization with Moroccan culture.
Rosa learns from Gannu, who is a curandera, about the power of language.
Rosa hybridizes her Western scientific knowledge with the tradition and natural medicine of Morocco.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This article examines the relationship between the Spanish Protectorate in Morocco (established in 1912 following the Treaty of Fez) and the Darqāwiyya religious brotherhood (ṭarīqa). It traces the origins and development of the Darqāwiyya order, its interactions with French and Spanish colonial powers, and its involvement in rebellions and political movements in Northern Morocco. The study details the colonial perception of the Darqāwiyya as a potential threat due to its social and religious influence and explores the shifting dynamics between the brotherhood's leaders and colonial agents. The establishment of the Spanish Protectorate in 1912 is a key backdrop, influencing the study's focus on the Darqāwiyya's role and interactions within that specific colonial context.
extracted_key_facts: The European colonial enterprise in North Africa was supported by a scientific and academic system complementing military action.
Morocco, like other territories under European control, became an object of study for colonization and control.
Religious brotherhoods (ṭurūq) in Morocco held great social and religious power and influence.
The Darqāwiyya was the most influential ṭarīqa in the Spanish Protectorate of Morocco.
The Darqāwiyya was considered a dangerous agent by Spanish information services due to its client networks and social and religious prestige.
The Spanish colonial government was established in 1912 and dominated by the military due to rebellions and uprisings against colonial power.
After hostilities ended in 1927, Spanish information services increased surveillance of Darqāwiyya leaders.
AbūʿAbd Allāh Muḥammad al-ʿArabī al-Darqāwī (d. 1823) founded the Darqāwiyya.
Around 1788, al-Darqāwī founded his first zāwiya in his cabila of origin, in BūBarīḥ.
The Darqāwiyya expanded rapidly, encompassing all social classes and extending into Oranesado (western Algeria).
The French landed near Algiers in July 1830, causing panic in Morocco.
Sultan ʿAbd al-Raḥmān (r. 1822-1859) intervened on the side of the Algerian emir ʿAbd al-Qādir against the French.
In August 1844, French forces defeated the Sultan's army at the Battle of Isly, leading to the Treaty of Tangier and the Convention of Lalla Maghniyya.
Colonialism created a negative view of the ṭarīqa and its followers because some leaders took part in localized revolts.
Captain De Neveu was one of the first authors to spread the negative image of the Darqāwa as a threat to the colonial enterprise.
The Spanish established the capital of their Protectorate in Tetuán in 1912.
AbūʿAbd Allāh Muḥammad bin Muḥammad binʿUmar al-Ḥarrāq (d. 1845) founded the al-Ḥarrāqiyya zāwiya in Tetuán around 1828.
SīdīʾIdrīs al-Ḥarrāq (d. 1934) established client relationships with the Spanish upon the establishment of the Protectorate.
In 1912, the Protectorate treaties of France and Spain defined the zones of influence and the international status of Tangier.
Muḥammad bin al-Ḥayy al-Ṣiddīq al-Ghumārī (1878-1936) directed the construction of the Darqāwiyya zāwiya in Tangier in 1903-1904.
Aḥmad al-Raysūnī facilitated Spanish operations, believing Spaniards were strong enough to help but not to oppress.
Following the establishment of the Spanish Protectorate in Tetuán, an insurrection led by sharīf Muḥammad bin Sīdī Laḥsan was organized.
Dámaso Berenguer became High Commissioner in February 1919 and began a war to conquer al-Raysūnī's territories.
In July 1921, after the Disaster of Annual, the Spanish military made a pact with al-Raysūnī, who regained his former power.
In January 1925, Chauen was taken by Aḥmad bin Muḥammad al-Ḥuzmarī, and al-Raysūnī was imprisoned and died in April of that year.
ʿAbd al-Krim's army was massacred in Annual and Monte Arruit.
In August 1921, ʿAbd al-Krim attacked the zāwiya of Tusgan.
On April 15, 1925, ʿAbd al-Krim burned the Darqāwiyya zāwiya of ʿAmyūṭṭ, and shaykh al-Darqāwī took refuge in Fez.
The Treaty of Bāb Tāza in 1927 concluded the "pacification" of the Spanish Protectorate zone.
From the establishment of the Protectorate, colonial authorities sought to attract the shuyūkh to facilitate penetration into cabilas under their authority.
At the end of 1932, some cabileños from Ajmas contacted the sharīf of Tusgan who connected them with the Franciscans of Tangier.
The Ḥizb al-Islāḥ al-Dīnī (Party of Religious Renovation) was created and led by the shaykh of Darqāwiyya of Tetuán.
From 1936, Sahrīf Aḥmad BinṢiddīq engaged in a double game during the Spanish Civil war.
The shaykh of Tánger attacked nationalists with the Spanish paying him.
In February 1950, the 'conspiracy darqāwa' took place involving a supposed introduction of armaments from Tánger.
